awd_titl_txt: P2C2:   Synthesis Study of the Tropical Rain Belt Through the Holocene
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is motivated by the idea that the tropical rain belt (TRB), including the oceanic and continental Inter-tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) and seasonal monsoon systems, plays a fundamental role in the Earth's climate and strongly impacts societies, ecosystems, and global climate.  During the Holocene, forced changes in the TRB have been invoked to explain many observed failures and increases in tropical rainfall. However, the physical processes driving changes in TRB dynamics and their relationship to climate forcings remain unclear.

This award generally aims to evaluate the drivers of Holocene TRB variations by utilizing a wide network of tropical paleo-hydroclimate records and new isotope-enabled model simulations.  This project aims to: (1) evaluate the response of the TRB's distinct components (convergence over ocean and land, and seasonal monsoons) to Holocene climate forcing functions and feedbacks, including biogeophysical feedbacks and interactions with ENSO; and (2) translate changes in the TRB into changes in proxy recorders, including those based on precipitation isotope ratios.

The scientific objectives of this project will be achieved through a synthesis of climate proxy records of TRB position and intensity and a series of model experiments with NCAR's isotope-enabled Community Earth System Model (CESM).  Time slices at different stages of the Holocene will provide a climate dynamical context for the synthesized data product. A set of sensitivity experiments will help determine the degree to which biosphere-atmosphere feedbacks and ENSO/TRB (El Nino-Southern Oscillation) interactions influence both isotopic and non-isotopic proxies. A toolkit of emerging proxy system models will be integrated into CESM to compare directly with the network of proxy records. It is expected that this project will help evaluate the forced changes in the TRB projected for the 21st century.

The Broader Impacts include upgrading and maintaining the isotopic version of the CESM, enabling the development of a post-doctoral scholar community at the institution, developing discovery-based undergraduate educational experiences, and adding new scientific data and analyses to help improve the understanding of natural climate variability.

por.por_cntn:
Stable isotope ratios of precipitation depend on source evaporative conditions, condensation amount, and distribution of transport paths. Analysis of modern records of isotope ratios in tropical precipitation showed that while there is no universally strong correlation with hydrological parameters, which is in contrast to the naive expectation that isotope ratios are a direct proxy for precipitation amount. Instead, either precipitation amount or moisture transport can dominate within regional domains in a manner consistent with regional hydro-climatology. The result enables proxy records to be similarly understood from a more complete evaluation of the hydrological cycle rather than a single parameter.

For the mid-Holocene period, 6000 years before present, the enhanced summertime solar radiation intensifies the monsoon circulation of Southeast Asia and India. It was found that the enhancement can be described as a combination of a northward shift in the extent of the intertropical convergence zone, the extent and magnitude of the overturning Hadley cell, or a change in the local magnitude and spatial extent of precipitation. Each of these features provide a different isotopic fingerprint, that is potentially detectable in the existing network of paleoclimate records. Changes in the precipitation amount at several speleothem sites was found mostly linked to northward migration of the location of maximum precipitation.

For evaluating mid-Holocene monsoon characteristics, the impact of changes to vegetation distribution are essential. The isotopic tracer scheme within the NCAR Community Earth System Model (CESM) demonstrated the importance of north African vegetation in properly simulating the distribution of isotope ratios in precipitation. Results show that in the region of the southeast Asian proxy records, the impact comes from changes to moisture transport pathways. The teleconnected circulation pattern that emerges from the African vegetation promotes stronger on-shore moisture flow from the Pacific Ocean and South China Sea. This in turn influences the monsoon season isotope ratios to be higher than otherwise in a manner which contradicts the conventional interpretation that high precipitation totals correlated with lower isotope ratios. The teleconnected circulation pattern has some similarity with the western tropical Pacific surface pressure pattern that emerges during La Nina conditions, and also is similar to changes in the mean state circulation due only to the northern summertime solar forcing. Using a network of isotopic records from the mid-Holocene, it was found that CESM likely underestimates the magnitude of the mean state response, and specifically the strength of the pacific moisture source relative. The synthesis of proxy data and model solutions provides a robust framework for leveraging the modeling tools to evaluate spatial coherence in changes to the tropical rain belt.
